Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center For Sustainable Energy Smart Solutions (SUESS)

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Planning Grants for Engineering Research Centers competition was run as a pilot solicitation within the ERC program. Planning grants are not required as part of the full ERC competition, but intended to build capacity among teams to plan for convergent, center-scale engineering research.

This award supports planning for a Center-scale project addressing Distributed Energy Resources (DER). DER such as rooftop solar, electric vehicles, controllable air conditioners and water heaters are connecting in increasing numbers. However, DER requires massive amounts of coordination supported by real-time information flows. There are well-known technical integration challenges with this transition, but just as importantly, there are non-technical challenges that are often overlooked. Specifically, consumers and local communities may not accept DER due to privacy issues, risk perceptions, distributional and procedural fairness. Such concerns can derail the transition to a smart and sustainable energy future. To grow to the requisite scale for real-world impact, renewables and DER require an interdisciplinary approach that integrates technical and socio-behavioral considerations. It is clear that such an effort will require a collaborative, transdisciplinary approach, which is exemplar of convergent research; the merging of approaches and insights from historically distinct disciplines to address problems that exist at the interface of multiple fields. This project supports an interdisciplinary planning process, with engineers and social scientists, industry, and policy makers, led by Cornell and engaging current and new partners to provide national leadership to address this challenge.

The grant will plan a Center with the capacity to address the interdisciplinary technical and socio-behavioral challenges to DER integration into smart grids. The PIs will apply innovative research in the science of team science (SciTS), and the design and development of the transdisciplinary research vision toward a shared, crucial, societal objective, which has not been widely applied in engineering research. Solutions at scale will not be adopted without involving social scientists in the engineering design processes up front, and therein lies a core component of the intellectual merit of the proposed planning process. The planning process for a potential Engineering Research Center (ERC) is distinctive in its deep, effective collaboration across a disciplinary chasm that is rarely bridged effectively. Thus, in addition to innovative collaborative research in massively distributed smart electric systems and community psychology, the proposed planning strategy will provide a case application in SciTS and ensure maximal transition of knowledge to societal impact.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This report covers outcomes of the Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Sustainable Energy Smart Solutions (SUESS).  The primary objective of this planning grant  was to strategize an innovative Engineering Research Center to address specific technical and social challenges for the sustainable grid of the future; comprised of diverse and distributed resources including renewables, storage, responsive demand and increased electric vehicle integration. The vision of the ERC was a collaboration among academic, government, and industry stakeholders across the country and around the world. The planning strategy was structured on Local Stakeholder Workshops, External Collaborative Workshops, and Team formation and collaboration. The expected benefits of the planning grant were to facilitate a structured approach for strategic team building and enable this team in design and development of the transdisciplinary ERC vision toward a shared, crucial, societal objective. 

 

The planning process engaged academic institutions of diverse types, industry, policymakers, and communities. The effort sought to develop new strategies for engagement of students, researchers and other stakeholders. This objective was achieved through various workshops, meetings and collaborative projects. One example worth highlighting was the student engagement in our sustainable energy innovation ecosystem, achieved through our virtual hackathon that brought together teams from around the world, representing diverse disciplines (Engineering, Computer Science, Social Science, Economics, Business and Design) participating from North America, South America, Africa and Asia. As a first virtual event, the students, industrial partners, and the leadership team, learned new ways of engaging and innovating and we look forward to hosting this event again in 2021. 

 

The case study around our application of Science of Team Science (SciTS) continues to be an experiment that will be relevant to other deep collaborations across disparate fields. We know that engineers have great skill in solving complex problems, but the solutions are meaningless if society fails to adopt them, so early and ongoing engagement across these fields is essential to large scale impact. Our proposed approach of social scientists, computer scientists, and engineers in shared leadership, from inception of problem formation, and throughout the solution design process, represents a new paradigm in an ERC framework. The team learned that the Science of Team Science is a complex and long-term undertaking that is both successful, and still a work in progress. The SuESS team has successfully shepherded our growing interdisciplinary collaboration through the duration of the planning grant and extended through the global pandemic. Such resilience is, in itself, a testament to the strength of the team that was an outcome of the SuESS ERC Planning project.
